content.description: Start with the decent left and good right hand under the shelf. Move up onto the shelf and mantle up with a high heel hook or lower feet. Stand up and finish over the middle.

Start: Standing - Both hands on good crimps about half way up the right side of the dihedral, your left foot on a decent sloper and your right foot flagged around the arete. 

 First move is into a sharp thumb-press mantel with your left hand.  Then, match your right foot on the starting foot hold and get a left-hand-foot match on the mantel.  From there, bring your left hand up into an 'Okay' left-side pull crimp.  Finally, get your right hand up to a good crimp, just to the right of the side-pull; get your right foot on the staring hand holds and top out on the boulder.  

 ***Note - This may already be an established route but, I have not been able to find any information on it.
content.protection: 1 Double pad will get the job done but, a half-pad on the tree can be nice.
content.location: In the dihedral at the end of Devil's Traverse.

content.description:
Start: Standing - Both hands on good crimps about half way up the right side of the dihedral, your left foot on a decent sloper and your right foot flagged around the arete.

 Beginning of this is the same as Spider's Nest Dihedral: First move is into a sharp thumb-press mantel with your left hand.  Then, match your right foot on the starting foot hold and get a left-hand-foot match on the mantel.  From there, bring your left hand up into an 'Okay' left-side pull crimp.  Next, get your right hand up to a good crimp, just to the right of the side-pull.  

 Where it differs: Once your right hand in on the good crimp, left hand out to a sharp crimp, over a slopey rail(this should make sense when you feel the hold); bring right foot in, match and then throw for the top of the boulder, there is a good rail.  Finally, get a high left foot on the lower part of the ledge and top out.

 ***Note - This may already be an established route but, I have not been able to find any information on it.
content.protection: 2 pads and a good spotter for the top out.
content.location:
In the dihedral at the end of Devil's Traverse.

 If you don't like spiders, I would not recommend.  The day I was working this, they were all over the rock.

content.description: Very easy warmup route, or something beginners can do if they can't do much else. There's a diagonal handhold running up and left to right. The feet are a little tough and slabby, but once one has the good handhold, you're golden.
content.location: Immediately to the right of The Wave, same boulder as The Vill, but on the other side from The Vill.

content.description:
Sit start with two underclings.  The large unattached rock right at the base of the boulder is off for feet! Work your left hand around and then up to a small slopey rail. Bring your right hand up to the right edge of the original feature. 

  This next move is the crux. A high left heel / whole foot smear on the feature helps!  

  Either make a big move with your right hand out to a crimpy sidepull, or make a weird side mantle move with your right hand and slap it way up to the slopey lip.  Match the slopey lip and top it out without using the really good jugs to the left.
content.location: Left corner of the boulder that Junior is on.

content.description:
A short but fun slab climb with tiny, almost non-existent footholds. Start on the horizontal crack a little more than halfway up the boulder. The really good foothold on the left, at the start of the problem is off; the first move was way too easy with that foot.  The right arete is also off. From the start, go right hand to a solid crimp, then left hand to a gaston. Get your left foot up super high to the starting crack, and move to the good horizontal crack near the top of the boulder. Match, and top out.  

  The crux move is definitely moving from the gaston to the horizontal crack.  The best way we found to make this move was to get your left foot super high.   

  The holds are not terrible - most of them are tiny crimps, but this is a slab problem.  What makes this climb tough is the absolute lack of feet; make use of any small divot in the rock that you can.
content.location: Facing The Wave boulder/problems, walk counterclockwise.  Find the slabby boulder.

content.description: Same start as Go Make Some Babies, move left along the crack and top out by moving around the corner with a heel and mantle.
content.location: Piston boulder in Devils Half Acre

content.description: No text - use the 'Improve This Page' link to add something useful!
